Gaussian Sum Approximations in Nonlinear Filtering and Control*
D.L.ALSPACH
Department of Applied Mechanics and Engineering Sciences,

ABSTRACT
This paper presents a survey of some recent results in the fields of nonlinear filtering and stochastic control resulting from the use of Gaussian sum approximations to certain density functions. When trying to estimate and control the state of a nonlinear stochastic dynamic system from noisy measurement data, the a posteriori density of the state conditioned on the measurement data contains all of the available information about the system state. If these densities were available, it should be possible to develop "optimal" estimation and control policies. The well-known Bayesian recursion relations describe the evolution of this a posteriori density in terms of given a priori densities, the system dynamics and measurement equations and the available data. Unfortunately, it is seldom possible to solve these closed forms for the required a posteriori densities. Over the last few years it has been shown that when the a priori densities are approximated by a sum of Gaussian densities with positive weighting coefficients that linear non-Gaussian problems can be solved analytically and that new natural solutions to nonlinear problems are available. Recently this method has been extended to dual deterministic optimal control problems.
1. INTRODUCTION
It has been known for some time that in order to model many physical, chemical, biological, and other systems adequately one must use mathematical models which take into account the stochastic nature of the systems under consideration. Such systems can seldom be observed in such a way that the total system behavior or state is known precisely at all times. Rather, the system is observed through measurement of variables which yield incomplete information and which contain unknown or random errors. In order to study the systems behavior or to control that behavior, it is generally necessary to estimate, from the contaminated measurement data and the stochastic dy- namical system equations, the state of the system and certain unknown param- eters of the system. In addition it is frequently necessary to take some type of control action based on these estimates.
The problem of finding an optimal control policy based on some performance criteria involves, except for certain simple cases, a complex combination of the

estimation problem and the control performance criterion. However, the estima- tion problem can be considered separately from the control problem and, in this sense, is the simpler of the two.
The problem of estimating the state of a nonlinear stochastic system from noisy measurement data has been the subject of considerable research interest during the past few years, but, although a great deal has been published on the subject, the basic objective of obtaining a solution that can be implemented in a straightforward manner for specific applications has not been satisfactorily realized. This is manifested by the fact that the Kalman filter equations [1,2], which are valid only for linear, Gaussian systems, continue to be widely used for nonlinear, non-Gaussian systems. Of course, continued application has resulted in the development of ad hoc techniques [3-5] that have improved the perfor- mance of the Kalman filter and which give it some of the characteristics of non- linear filters.
However, as more and more emphasis is placed on optimum system perfor- mance, the available estimation and control policies for inherently stochastic sys- tems must be improved. As the system models improve and computers with greater capability become available, it will be necessary to develop techniques which utilize all pertinent existing information to obtain such policies. The ability to utilize all of the information contained in non-Gaussian densities and to propagate this through nonlinear plants will be essential for this purpose.
Central to the nonlinear estimation and stochastic control problems is the determination of the probability density function of the state conditioned on the available measurement data. This density contains all information which is theoretically available concerning the state of the system. Thus, if this a posteriori density function were known, an estimate of the state of any per- formance criterion could be determined. Unfortunately, although the manner in which the density evolves with time and additional measurement data can be described in terms of difference (or differential) equations, these relations are generally very difficult to solve, either in closed-form or numerically, so that it is usually impossible to determine the a posteriori density for specific applica- tions. Because of this difficulty, it is natural to investigate the possibility of approximating the density with some tractable form. One approach to the solu- tion of this problem and some results which have been obtained are discussed below.

The nonlinear filtering problem is solved when the density p (x^lz^) can be obtained for all k, however, except when the system (1)-(2) is linear and the a priori distributions are Gaussian, it is generally impossible to determine pCx^i1') in a closed form using (3)-(5). In the linear Gaussian case, the relations de- scribing the conditional mean and covariance ofp(xfc|zk) are the well-known Kalman filter equations [2]. The difficulties associated with the explicit determination of the a posteriori density have led to the development of approx- imate procedures for estimating the state of nonlinear stochastic systems. The most commonly used approximation involves the assumptions that the a priori distributions are Gaussian and that the nonlinear system can be linearized rela- tive to latest estimate yielding the "extended" Kalman filter which has seen widespread application to nonlinear systems [2, 5,7].
The extended Kalman filter has performed well in many applications but there are numerous examples in which unsatisfactory results have been obtained. This has spurred the development of other procedures. Most of these either im- plicitly or explicitly, retain the assumption that^xJz^ is Gaussian and essen- tially provide a means for modifying the mean and covariance of the density. However, the Gaussian assumption greatly reduces the generality or richness of possible a posteriori densities throwing out all possibility of more realistic multi- modal densities.
For this reason, the Gaussian sum method discussed below was developed allowing the approximation of general a posteriori densities for nonlinear non- Gaussian systems.

This can be proven by appealing to Wiener's theorem on approximation [8], by direct proof [9] or be considering delta functions of the positive type [10]. Thus this class of density functions is rich enough to approximate all density functions of engineering interest arbitrarily well.
The second problem of obtaining specific approximations to a given a priori density has been solved in two ways. First, one may reduce the problem to a deterministic optimization problem and perform a numerical search for the parameters of the Gaussian sum [9, 10]. The results of such approximation are shown in Figs. 1 and 2. A fair amount of computer time is required to solve for each approximate density. A second method based on the concept of delta functions of positive type has proven more useful in practice. It has been found that very adequate approximations can be obtained with no numerical search simply by first spacing the Gaussian means uniformly over the region of state space of interest, and secondly by choosing the variance to give a smooth fit. In this approach, the weighting factors, a are chosen proportional to the magni- tude of the value of the function to be approximated at the appropriate points. Examples of Gaussian sum approximation to several densities which were ob- tained by this method are shown in Figs. 3-5. Other examples are contained in the references.
4. LINEAR SYSTEMS WITH GAUSSIAN NOISE BUT NON-GAUSSIAN INITIAL STATE
When the system and measurement equations are linear and all the a priori densities are Gaussian, all the a posteriori densities are also Gaussian with the mean and covariance given by the Kalman filter. Thus the densities are re- producing [11] in the sense that each density has the same form. When all of

This use of Gaussian sums for nonlinear filtering was mentioned by Aoki as early as 1965 [12] and has been considered by Cameron [13], Lainiotis [15, 18], and Lo [17], as well as Alspach and Sorenson [9, 10]. This case is particularly interesting since after the initial approximation of the density p(xo) by a Gaussian sum density, one obtains the exact solution of the Bayesian recursion relations. All of the terms of the sum propagate forward in time by a set of independent Kalman filter equations, while all nonlinear dependence on the measurement data is contained in the weighting coefficients. 5. LINEAR SYSTEMS WITH NON-GAUSSIAN NOISE AND INITIAL STATE
If the linear measurements [2] are contaminated by non-Gaussian noise or the linear system [1] is driven by non-Gaussian noise, one must extend the method discussed in the last section. If one simply replaces the non-Gaussian
284 D. L. ALSPACH
plant and measurement noise densities by Gaussian densities of the same mean and covariance, a great deal of information may be lost and nonmeaningful estimates obtained. However, if good Gaussian sum approximations of p(ujc) and p(Wfc) are found, one may still solve the Bayesian recursion relations (3)-(5) analytically [9, 10]. The resulting recursion relations are similar to those discussed in Sec. 4 involving a number of Kalman filters evolving in parallel with the nonlinear dependence on the measurements contained in the weighting coefficients. The a posteriori densities resulting can be made as accurate as desired by choice of the initial approximations [9].
The recursion relations are still reproducing in the sense that all the a posteriori densities are still of the Gaussian sum form. However, to be truly reproducing the number of terms in the sum at each stage should remain con- stant. This is only the case when only the initial density is non-Gaussian. When either the plant or measurement noise density is a Gaussian sum with more than one term, the number of terms in the exactly calculated a posteriori densities grows from stage to stage. It has been shown [10] that there are two factors which can lead to the restriction of this growth by the use of natural approxi- mations. The first arising from the form of the weighting coefficients of each term allows one to drop negligible terms. These are terms in which the weight- ing coefficient has become exponentially small.

6. NONLINEAR SYSTEM
The most frequently used approach for the estimation of the state of a non- linear system involves the linearization of the system relative to a best estimated value for the state and the subsequent application of the Kalman filter equa- tions. This approach results in approximations of two types. First, the non- linear physical system is replaced by a linear model, and, second, the non- Gaussian a posteriori density function p(xfe I z1') is approximated by a Gaussian density. One other method that may be used on a small class of problems is to transform the nonlinear problem to a linear problem. When this can be done such that both the measurements and system are linear, one usually finds that the Gaussian noise has been transformed to non-Gaussian noise. Under these special conditions the method of Sec. 5 can be applied.
In Ref. [16], a filtering procedure is defined which is based on the utiliza- tion of the Gaussian sum representation of the a posteriori density function in conjunction with the linearization procedure that has proven so effective in

7. CONTROL THEORY
Often estimating the state of a system is only a stepping stone to allow the control of that system. This would be the case when the system (1) contains a control variable and one is to choose the control at each stage based on all previous measurement data to minimize the expected value of a cost function of the control and the state.
When the system is linear, it is well known that with a number of additional assumptions the principle of optimality can be used to prove that the optimal stochastic control problem can be solved by the solution of two independent problems. First, an optimal estimate of the system state conditioned on all available information is computed, and, secondly, a deterministic optimal con-
GAUSSIAN SUM APPROXIMATIONS IN NONLINEAR FILTERING 287
trol is calculated for the problem formed by replacing all a priori random vari- ables by their mean values. Under the rather fortuitous circumstances when the optimal control is composed of the optimal deterministic control with the state at time k replaced by the best estimate of the state at time k the separation theorem or separation principle is said to be valid. When this theorem does not apply, the control resulting from this combination of an optimal estimate with a deterministic control function is still often used and then the resulting control called the certainty equivalence control [20, 21 ]. It is partially the separation theorem and partially the extensive use of this suboptimal control that can ac- count for the large interest by control engineers in the inherently secondary problem of estimation theory. In Ref. [22], the proof of the separation theorem is extended using the Gaussian sum method to linear systems with quadratic cost but non-Gaussian initial state and non-Gaussian plant and measurement noise.
In the more common situation where the separation theorem does not apply, the more general dynamic programming approach has not been used partly be- cause of the curse of dimensionality but mostly because it is not generally possible to obtain the required a posteriori densities in the analytical form required by the algorithm. However, by using the approximate densities dis- cussed above preliminary investigation into the advantages to be gained from use of optimal and suboptimal dual controllers has been made [23]. This preliminary investigation indicates that there are potentially large benefits in improved performance of stochastic systems from the use of controls different from the certainty equivalence controls and which retain the dual nature of the truly optimal control. The use of approximate a posteriori densities of one form or another will be essential for this to be accomplished.
The Gaussian sum approach to deterministic control problems using the duality between optimal control for deterministic systems and estimation for stochastic systems has been investigated by Dajani and Campion [24], following the similar approach [9, 10, 13-18] to the dual linear-Gaussian estimation problem with non-Gaussian initial state-vector. The optimal control problem for nonlinear systems with nonquadratic final-cost function was solved by approximation of the Lyoponov function by a Gaussian sum.
8. DISCUSSION AND POTENTIAL FUTURE RESEARCH
There are several advantages and several limitations to the general approach considered here. First, all of this work is based on the Bayesian approach which must rest on the existence of the appropriate probability density functions. This may pose a conceptual problem, but will hardly affect engineering prob- lems of filtering and control. The nonlinear filters considered here require the
288 D.L. ALSPACH
existence of at least a first derivative of the plant and measurement nonlin- earities at the points of linearization. For a function that is nowhere differen- tiable different techniques must be considered. The solution to the Bayesian recursion relations can be implemented in a straightforward manner by the methods considered here for both linear and nonlinear, Gaussian and non- Gaussian problems to give approximate a posteriori density functions. These density functions can be made arbitrarily close to the true densities, however the computational requirements can easily become excessive as the number of terms grows. An interesting alternative implementation of this filter is studied in Ref. [25] which considers the use of parallel processing computers to exploit the intrensic parallel nature of these filters. This is a natural choice, since all the filters discussed here consist of a number of modulated Kalman or extended Kalman filters operating in parallel.
One advantage of this class of filter over some others that have been ad- vanced is the apparent ease with which symmetries in the state transition function and measurement nonlinearities can be utilized to reduce the com- putational complexity of a problem. A second advantage is the ease with which moments can be obtained once the density approximation is found [10]. An area of future work is the extension of the parallel processing work of Ref. [25]. The Gaussian sum filter should be implemented in detail on an existing parallel processing computer such as the ILLIAC IV and simulation results obtained.
There are several other areas requiring more detailed research. First, and most direct, is the application of these methods to a number of additional test problems. Several additional nonlinearities should be investigated as well as problems of higher dimension. Results obtained from these studies should be compared to other possible filters such as the linearized filters [3], the Senne- Bucy digital filters [26], and Spline filters [27]. The classes of problems which require or can justify nonlinear filtering should then be outlined and those classes of problems best suited to each of the recently developed nonlinear filtering methods should be mapped out. Possible combinations of the various methods for optimal results should also be considered. An interesting paper by Center on a generalized least-squares approach to the approximation of con- ditional density functions has already pointed out many similarities and relation- ships between the different approaches mentioned above [28]. These relation- ships mentioned earlier by Lainiotis [29] should be a logical starting place for a study of the relative usefulness of each method.
In addition to the above work, the basic filter algorithms should be extended to include such additional factors as nonadditive noise, state and control de- pendent noise, unknown plant and measurement covariance matrices, and un- known initial error covariance matrix. Lastly, but perhaps most important, is the continued development and study of stochastic controls which retain the dual nature of the optimal control and can be implemented in a realistic manner.
GAUSS1AN SUM APPROXIMATIONS IN NONLINEAR FILTERING 289
By using these general methods to obtain stochastic controllers and approxi- mations to optimal nonlinear filters, we will obtain a greater understanding of the nature of the problems, the nature of the truly optimal filter, and the dual nature of the optimal stochastic control. With this greater understanding, it may well be possible to implement an adequate filter or a greatly improved control in a much simpler manner than by the direct use of the methods dis- cussed here or in the references.

cja:head.ce:title: Gaussian Sum Approximations in Nonlinear Filtering and Control

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Applied Mechanics and Engineering Sciences, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California 92037 USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This paper presents a survey of some recent results in the fields of nonlinear filtering and stochastic control resulting from the use of Gaussian sum approximations to certain density functions. When trying to estimate and control the state of a nonlinear stochastic dynamic system from noisy measurement data, the a posteriori density of the state conditioned on the measurement data contains all of the available information about the system state. If these densities were available, it should be possible to develop “optimal” estimation and control policies. The well-known Bayesian recursion relations describe the evolution of this a posteriori density in terms of given a priori densities, the system dynamics and measurement equations and the available data. Unfortunately, it is seldom possible to solve these closed forms for the required a posteriori densities. Over the last few years it has been shown that when the a priori densities are approximated by a sum of Gaussian densities with positive weighting coefficients that linear non-Gaussian problems can be solved analytically and that new natural solutions to nonlinear problems are available. Recently this method has been extended to dual deterministic optimal control problems.
